Eurogamer 2012 Interview: Tiny Troopers

17/11/2012

Elliot Brooks chats to Chris Carver, the big mind behind Tiny Troopers

Image by

By undefined undefined

On the show floor at this years convention I had a chance to chat with Chris Carver of Kukouri Mobile Entertainment, who was showing off his new game Tiny Troopers. The game plays like an action-RTS with giddy visuals and satisfyingly squelchy explosions. I should note that Chris got his arse handed to him by the level he demonstrated to us. The game looks extremely fun and brutally difficult, and you could tell from the way Chris talked the serious level of passion and joy he and his team have poured into this energetic game. Definitely one to watch out for. It's available on mobile and PC, with the Android version on the verge of release. How does Tiny Troopers play? Well you get upgrades and as you kill things you get points. Like an RPG system, but we did this as one upgrade per mission. So you get an augmented scope for this mission because you're getting points so quickly. It just racks up. We didn't want to have an RPG levelling up system because the balancing of that is so hard. We tried balancing it, but it was very hard, but we're still trying it and if we ever get it working properly maybe we'll switch to that. For now this is working. Is the mobile version different from the PC version? It is going to have paid packs on iOS. It's not going to have packs on Android, that's not going to be the case. We have ad support there. You've gotta make your money for development because it's cost us something to develop. And Android has actually been the hardest one for us to develop for. It was easier for us to develop for the PC, which is why the PC's out first, than it has been for Android support because there's so many different types of device and hardware. I have a fully working version on the tablet here but the problem is that that one works but on your phone or some other person's phone, it might be all black and it's just the troopers and we have no idea that it's like that until Q&A comes back and says 'Hey it's like that.' So that's tough. So I take it that's different for the Apple OS. Is that easier to develop for? Oh, it's so much easier, it's a breeze. We loved developing there. We decided to go with PC in the first place, we weren't initially going to port to iOS at all, but in the development environment it basically looked like this [referred us to the screen he was playing on]. You see the nice flames and shadows. Very pretty. It's very pretty. But on iOS while it's still very pretty it's not this pretty and you can't have as many enemies, you can't have these particle effects just a lot of basic- [begins to lose a lot of health while playing] this is actually a very hard level. On mobile do you use the virtual analogue sticks, or touch controls? No, we tried so many different control schemes and it's just completely one tap. I'd say one of the things we're proudest of is the fact that we've got very simplified controls, it's no problem. You can really just jump right on it and get right into the game. We've played with the line type, like draw a line and make your guys go there or there, autofire or thumbsticks. None of it felt right and then we tried holding it and your finger is covering everything and you can't see anything. Why are we spending all this time doing these models when you can't see anything! Can you pull the assets straight across from PC to mobile? Do you have to recreate everything? We can port parts of it. But then we have to tweak it and spend time making it actually work and looking right and correct and what-not. And there's a lot on the PC that we had to do, like entirely brand new effects. They weren't supported, they were made from the ground up to be on here because the iOS one didn't look like that if you put them on the PC in this high resolution. How does it control for the PC version? You have either the keyboard controls - we just recently added those. We initially had it basically how Cannon Fodder controls, an almost exact copy of how Cannon Fodder controls - which was left mouseclick moves, right mouseclick shoots. That's what we wanted because we were going for that type of game, that hardness, that feel. And we raised it, and the community said they didn't like that, they wanted PC controls as well so we were like 'Okay, fine, we'll put it in.' We had it in, we had the code for it, we just didn't do it because we didn't think it was grand but apparently we were wrong! So we fixed it. So, taking the game to a convention like this, what does this do for your game? We're just trying to get noticed really. We're a very small company - there's only seven of us all together. Two of them are basically handling business and PR and stuff like that and then the five are actually making the game. With that size team, how long did it take you to put this game together? Eight, ten months, almost a year. We're still working on it. We're constantly updating and fixing things and still working on this and we're also working on another project, and we've actually got this on PC. But we're still working on the Android version, and as we fix things and work on the Android version we might fix a tree model - the PC gets that model, so will iOS. So what's next for your development circle? We can't really announce it! We are still working of course on Tiny Troopers and still up and going. The PC's going to see a zombie survival mode which the mobile already has, very soon. Then it's just hammering out the small little things that pop up. October 24th is when we finalise, so that'll come out as free DLC on Steam. Did you ever consider charging for the DLC? We thought about it for a while because the thing is - we're still working on it, and that's someone's salary. So we did think about it, but we had it working on iOS already and we decided to do it free on that one so we didn't really want to do it that way, so we ended up saying 'You know what - we'll just do it.' And we're still working on it now, so it's still costing us more money but the community appreciates that hey, yes, we're just going to do this. Do you think you'll keep supporting it then? Or will you move onto something new after that DLC? Hopefully we'll keep on supporting it, because it all comes down to cost. We're still supporting it well past when we probably should've moved on to something else but I don't know, if we get enough people loving it then of course we could add more to it. Would you ever open the game up to the community in terms of modding? Probably not. There's too many loopholes and jumping through legalese and what-not so it just wouldn't happen, it's probably not going to happen. In this convention have you had time to look around? Any games that you've noticed? I've only made it from here to the press room and back. That's the only time I've had so far. It's been a constant stream of people. What do you want to see then? What do I want to see? I'm probably going to go and see Dust, and there's quite a few things at the Indie Arcade, I'd like to go there and see what's happening. Have you taken this anywhere else as well? PAX was only a little while ago. I didn't drop over to PAX but I was over in Gamescom and E3 when we launched. At Gamescom was our PC launch. How did that compare to here? This is my baby because I made this happen. I set up all of the interviews, so it's my baby and I'm more excited here because it's mine. But Gamescom was really good compared to even, like, E3. E3 was my very first convention going to, and it was good, it was really crammed but there was a lot of press there and felt nice but I never got to see the floor, ever. So it was more stressful. Gamescom was extremely relaxed, especially as all the devs are there from GDC so it was a very relaxed environment. This one here has been even nicer, I'm loving it.
